												Crysis Warhead is a first person shooter, and is a standalone expansion top the original Crysis game. This was released in September 2008.Warhead follows a side plot to the original story of "Psycho", an ally of the original protagonist, Nomad. You are thrown into challenges on the other side of the island at the same time as the original story.  One change with the gameplay that Warhead brings, is the chance to customize your weapons, allowing you to put silencers, different sights on, and other additions such as flashlights. All of the weaponry which was in the first game is still present here, with the addition of a few new guns such as dual wielding SMGs which are absolutely bad-♥♥♥.  We see the return of the super human style nanosuit too. Warhead features a optimized version of the Cry Engine 2, but it still lacks 1080P resolutions which is a real shame. The game still looks really nice and blows alot of recently released titles out of the water graphically, even though it is almost eight years old now. The graphics menu has interesting options available, you are basically having to pick the style of gamer you are; you get pigeon holed into categories such as "gamer" or "enthusiast" for example - to me this really doesn't look good. I should be able to pick the graphics options with their regular choices, and not some predefined garbage categories which we see here.  The lack of high resolutions slightly lets the game down. There is a hot-fix you can do by changing .ini file settings, but this also messes with frame rates, and lord knows what else. The story is a complete stand alone to the original game, you can play this game first and still be none the wiser that their is a prequel to it. I really like the idea that all of this story is going on at the same time as the original though, it makes the plot seem even deeper than before. Warhead has some well recorded voice acting, all be it a very generic English accent on the main character, but all of the other dialogue and sound effects are all very good. This game has various difficulties, much like the original. Playing on Delta mode, which is the hardest, will certainly give you a well worthy challenge if you are an experienced Crysis/FPS player, stick to the lower difficulties if you just want to see the story as enemies and gameplay takes a significant drop in difficulty. Warhead, much like Crysis 1, could sometimes be considered as an open world game. The levels which you are playing in, are absolutely huge. There are so many different methods of reaching the same location, that you can play this game exactly how you want it. I personally opted to try a more stealthy approach, and normally games don't really cater for different methods like that, but I was still able to experience everything the same. There are tons of little nuggets of extra story to find throughout each level too, from computers to checkout, to radio broadcasts of propaganda. Plenty of stuff to keep you looking in every building you come across. A full playthrough of Crysis Warhead will take you just about five hours; depending on how you play. My first run through was a regular all gungho all guns blazing playthrough, which took me just about four hours to complete. My second run, which was my stealthy approach, took me quite a bit longer. Normally I don't get as much enjoyment out of my second run through a game, but I was able to get the same, and if not more enjoyment out of a second playthrough, I was able to see a different side to the game which I didn't see before in the regular playthrough, and the higher difficulties add a little bit more replay ability too. As well as the aforementioned resolution issues I had. I did notice a little bit of screen tearing on the cut scenes. Turning on v-sync tanks the frame rate to sub 30, which is unacceptable. nVidia users can enable v-sync in their control panel but you will still get a bit of tearing sadly. I guess that's what you get from older direct 9 version of games when you are running more recent operating systems/direct x versions.Crysis Warhead definitely stands the test of time when it comes to gameplay and story; it's hard to believe that this game is almost eight years old now. You wouldn't think so with the quality of the gameplay on show. It is a welcome addition to the Crysis franchise and one that should almost certainly be played by fans of the series, and just FPS fans in general.  For the low price of £7,99, you will be getting a significant length story mode, with plenty of replay ability with a very fleshed out story line to boot. 												If you can find my user review for the original Crysis I noted how the quality of its level design seems to fall off a cliff later in the campaign. A lot of other people will probably tell you this too. Warhead feels as if Crytek made it specifically to address that problem. It’s pretty much a more tightly-designed package of Crysis levels with a couple new weapons and vehicles.If you were actually interested in what the original Crysis game’s story was about I don’t know what to say, but Warhead’s is slightly better. It’s kind of like the difference between Predator and The Rock respectively, the latter being slightly less cheesy, but still bombastic in its own way. Warhead follows Psycho (the British guy) and features a somewhat decently played-out character arc between him and a new supporting character. That’s all I think I can really say about it.Aside from the original game’s suit powers, a new grenade launcher, EMP grenades which weaken nanosuit-equipped enemies (who are far more common in this expansion) but you as well, drivable APCs, and a couple new kinds of mounted gun, Warhead’s selling point is its superior level design compared to the original game. Luckily the level designers managed to stay strong throughout. Crysis is a game that, behind its graphics, is hailed for open-ended mission design reminiscent of GoldenEye or Thief with huge maps. Ironically, almost all Warhead’s missions are pretty linear compared to the first game’s. But it manages to be linear without feeling like a Call of Duty-style corridor. It’s a very “wide” sort of linear.The first mission ends with an open-ended base infiltration similar to some levels from Crysis, but after that everything is technically a straight line that still manages to give you a lot of options in how you play the game. The vehicle chase sequence immediately following that infiltration somehow doesn’t feel like a scripted event but instead simply has you follow a target within an open area. This is followed by what is, actually, a pretty well-done boss fight to contrast with the first game’s mediocre final boss. Afterwards there’s a section inside a battleship where Crytek actually manages to play some scripting tricks on you without automatically controlling the camera or putting you in a quick time event or anything. It’s almost more Half-Life 2 than Black Ops in this way. Warhead makes even its literal tunnels dynamic enough to let players have a say in how they tackle each combat situation, including a train section.Visually, Warhead looks slightly better than the original Crysis but hasn’t had nearly as many mods made for it. Fortunately Crytek actually tried to optimize Warhead a bit so for most people the game should run better than Crysis. Warhead’s highest graphical features also aren’t locked behind DirectX 10.Compared to the first Crysis, Warhead is kind of like the same meal with the same ingredients but prepared more diligently after the chef got some experience.

												Crysis Warhead's level design is noticeably different than that of Crysis 1. It still has both open and tight levels (which are alternated between for better pacing), but they are presented differently this time around. The open levels don't quite offer the same freedom of approach and alternate routes as the first game, presenting instead a wide but more straightforward route to your objective. The tighter sections are much better designed and are pretty fun to fight in. Warhead is also more action-oriented, often rushing you into a battle rather than letting you approach a potential encounter from a distance. Fortunately, the game still offers plenty of freedom and options for the player to handle confrontations. Improvements over the first game include the alien enemies, boss battles and vehicle controls. Overall, a short but highly enjoyable campaign.

At some point in the original Crysis, you two split up to handle separate missions, this game takes place right after that and ends right before you meet back up in the original, thus, it is a fairly short game.Story: 8/10Because it is in the same time-frame and environment as the original Crysis, not much needs to be explained. This game came out approximately a year after the original, which means they optimized their code and this didn't make my computer want to cry. It runs smoother and looks cleaner, and is completely action-packed from the get-go. Also, the cut scenes are in third person, which I feel is an improvement so you can see how your character is reacting to his situation as it develops. As far as audio, it sounds about the same quality as the original Crysis so all is good in this department. Gameplay: 8/10Same game as Crysis, but in my personal opinion, I had more fun before the aliens show up. By the way, the game is Gamepad enabled if you want it to be.Overall: 9/10It isn't the original Crysis, and that isn't necessarily BAD. This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Crysis Warhead skip to Results and read from there.Crytek creates another epic continuation onto the Crysis series. Crysis Warhead offers an alternative story from the eyes of Physco another one of the nano-tech marines. Story:On the same island as the original Crysis Warhead starts the story with Sergeant Sykes, Physco, who is on a vital mission to capture Korean cargo. It is up to you and your friend O’neil to push through the forces of North Korea and aliens alike to complete your objective. Campaign:The campaign consists of approximately seven missions, which vary in length. The campaign lasts anywhere from around four to seven hours depending on your play method. The initial missions are before are against human AI, but as you progress the enemy shift begins to occur as you start fighting less humans and engaging more aliens. The enemies, weapons, and abilities are the same as the original meaning this expansion only adds new missions and story. Regardless the campaign is well planned and the levels keep you wanting for me. They offer  dynamic play-styles that allow you to choose your completion style. Gameplay:As in the original the gameplay varies based on your difficulty. I played Delta and noticed most of the game was more about utilizing my cloak ability and catching enemies by surprise. The enemies will fire in the same place if you cloak and run, but if you hide for a few seconds they tend to forget you even existed and continue on with their business. Realistically this game is pretty fun and the combat can be dynamic – if you’re looking for run and gun you’d probably want to play on an easy difficulty. On the other hand if you’re more into sneak and strike then I’d recommend going for a harder difficulty. The abilities are fun, but you’ll notice you tend to use some over others. I rarely found myself using speed or super-strength, but instead almost exclusively cloak and shields (which auto selects when cloak deactivates). Hints:>If you cloak in mid battle and move prone most of the time you can avoid actually having to move as the enemies will be shooting above you.>If you see a gun with an attachment you have make sure to drop your gun and exchange for that one. Otherwise you won’t unlock the attachment.>The Plasma Accumulator Cannon only fires a short range then explodes sending missiles outwards.  This means to really damage your enemies you need to get close to them. >IF you use a flashlight or a laser and cloak they can give away your position.Results:All and all Cyrsis Warhead is a great addition to the series and even if you didn’t play the first Crysis I would recommend giving it a go. It doesn’t really ruin any elements from the original if you play them backwards, but adds more depth to your Physco who in the first game seemed rather annoying. The campaign offers great complexity and amazing new environments. The graphics are of par to the original, annoyingly not 1080p, but still it looks good enough that you couldn’t tell anyway. I’d definitely recommend this game for someone who loves FPS games. Pros:+Suit abilities which allow you to change up your combat style.+Loads of different weapons with unique attachments: silencers, lasers, flashlights, grenade launchers, etc.+Decent enemy AI and good combat mix.+Smooth difficulty curve accommodating for various skill levels.+Good length campaign, which offers many new environments and combat scenarios.+Good story and addition to the continuation of the series. Cons:-Not too many check points, you can manually save but sometimes you’d forget in the head of battle die and be warped back to what seems like the beginning of the level.

												A shorter, honed in take on Crysis, Warhead delivers a slightly tweaked take on the original game in a more linear, but excitement packed expansion.There's a distinct change in tone between Crysis and Warhead and whilst the game largely plays the same, having a more vocal and at the very least charismatic main character gives Warhead a more personal touch than Crysis ever had. There's a perhaps greater emphasis on action as you're carried from encounter to encounter, but this generally feels like an improvement over potentially mundane driving sequences in the original. The only major criticism I have of the game is its length. Whilst it maintains a brisk pace from start to finish, it does end after not too long a play-time, howerver it doesn't feel like a let down given its approach as a sort of side-quest from the main game. Of questionable worth in of itself, as an addition to Crysis it provides a really fun accompliament such that if the original was of interest, Warhead should certainly not be ignored.

												Warhead was the successor of Crysis in 2008; a stand-alone expansion pack that was specifically released for PCs and, interestingly, did not require the original Crysis game to run. I remember this being praised for its better optimisation while the game at the same time had the exact same requirements as its predecessor. Also it looks better, there's not much difference, though, as it uses the same environments / assets as the original Crysis game.The story is a tad bit unusual here - instead of this being a continuation to Crysis it actually takes place at the same time. However, the game puts us in the shoes of Psycho instead of Nomad. We pick up the story just after the two buddies get separated - with Psycho alone there's more focus on fighting the Korean military (initially, that is) as the emphasis is on retrieving / destroying the nuclear warhead they have in their possession (hence the title). I liked the in-game cutscenes they made for the game and the fact that we have a Korean colonel as the game's antagonist.The campaign is, being part of an expansion pack, shorter than that of Crysis but is a BLAST! I found it more action-packed and interesting (even though we know there are aliens rampant on the island which is not a surprise anymore). Since multiplayer services no longer exist (see the disclaimer re GameSpy on the store page) there's no point in elaborating on that one. Perhaps there's a solution for that, but this would definitely be something unofficial. Thus, at this point, this game is only worth purchasing for its short but satisfying campaign content. If discounted, it may just be a decent purchase and then you can make up your mind whether or not you want to see what Crytek achieved with Crysis 2.

Teal DeerDevelopers: CrytekPublishers: Electronic Arts Initial release: Sept 2008Genre: Action, FPS, Standalone Add-on#Worth/NotWorth: #WorthExposition, Concurrence and Summation	Crysis Warhead is a standalone add-on or more accurately an addendum from a different perspective than that of Nomad from the first game. Warhead begins and takes place during the latter half of Crysis 1, roughly before the mission “Ascension”. You play as Michael Sykes better known as “Psycho”.  	It's got all the bells and whistles that Nomad's nanosuit had as well as the tactical options afforded by weapon modifications. It feels slightly more limited in map design and has trigger points that pull you out of the action more often which isn't ideal. 	Also the novelty of having such tactical options available are less enticing when the AI is for lack of a better word, abhorrent, in most cases. I once had about 9 enemies huddle into an alley behind a building just waiting to get ambushed. I also had an instance where I went into a building to complete a objective, completed that objective and proceeded to grab supplies from a nearby weapon cache only to turn around to find all the enemies had just now spawned into the building I just had infiltrated. It wasn't really an issue though. More chances to experiment as playing around with dashing and strength jumps never really gets old.  THE GIST This is a nice little standalone piece though I don't think it tells a very cohesive story to be honest should you not have played through Crysis 1. But to reiterate, I don't think that's the main draw. It's nice that it's there for some context. But really Crytek knows you're here to cloak shoot a gas tank off a hummer and watch the fire spread and pop the tires and proceed to have the jeep rip itself apart in a rather dramatic fashion.Follow my curation for more

												Pretty Good Game Review Considering (PGGRC) 5.5 Hours to CompleteTL;DR - Hidden gem and the grandfather of shooters to say the least. This is very similar to the original crysis but is much more of a standalone dlc to crysis and it shown by the 7 missions it has which is less than the 12 mission’s crysis had. It’s the same besides mission length (still good and varied) and the story is through the eyes of a different protagonist which makes little different. All in all both played is the perfect first person shooter package and will make you resent other first person shooters for not having the flexibility and fun of the crysis franchise. In depth: Performance - Well the game is old. 7 years old at the time of this review. Other games in comparison that are 7 years old look like ♥♥♥♥. It’s actually a lot better than the first crysis with better performance and slightly better graphics as the original crysis had random fps drops despite exceeding the hardware. This is very smooth with no frame drops. Graphics - So I said the game was smooth that must mean the game must look average right? Nope. Even now the game looks beautiful considering its 7 years old. The game in fact looks better than some games that came out this year. That shows that they actually value PC gaming and did not cash in with consoles the same way they did later on with crysis titles *cough* Crysis 2 and 3 *cough*. Gameplay - Now on to the gameplay: Solid. The gunplay is enjoyable and lots of different attachments which provides different opptunities against each enemy type. Each enemy is varied: From humans having a similar arsenal to you, flying squid aliens which ambush you and vehicles such as helis, jeeps and apcs that will need strategy to beat rather than a bigger gun, though that helps. Might I add that you can also drive them. You can see why I like this game? On top of that the nano suit brings you a new strategy to complete your objective. Armour making you a tank to go guns blazing, Stealth to be a cloak and dagger, dash to completely evade any enemy and strength to just throw ♥♥♥♥ at people. The game is so varied in how you approach objectives and how you complete them because of the open world map and the nano suit. Great in terms of depth and playstyles. Only drawback is the story which is very B-movie. It keeps the game going and gives you an excuse to enter new environments. The story is very generic; aliens evade, take them out, done. Its forgettable and basic so don’t buy it for that it’s the gameplay and graphics this rocks at.Replayability - A lot. With the playstyle, different weapons, attachments, routes, vehicles and pace can give totally new experiences. Not more to say then the time it took me I enjoyed every bit due to its flexibity and freedom lacking in game today. Conclusion - If you can’t tell I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game. Everything besides story just shows the potential and the missed chance many games coming out miss. It’s not about building a story then putting in gameplay. Gameplay is what makes this game because it only focuses on that and as a result it’s amazing and competes with many games out now. Any playstyle is rewarded with the nano suit, weapons, attachments and vehicles. You probably have got it but if you don’t, GET IT. Because Spelling Crysis normally isnt cool enough...This game is a Strong standalone expansion to the original Crysis game which was released on September 2008. Warhead follows a plot that happens during the original story of the first game and explains lots of things from the first game! You follow a Tough as Nails englishman Nicknamed "Pyscho" and he has a very interesting story to tell, although a short one!


Michael "Psycho" Sykes 
A Screenshot of Crysis Warhead
By: Jaeger




Warhead features a  clearly optimized version of the Cry Engine 2, with 720p graphics (good for the time.) with lots of settings to choose from. Lots of Mods are also avaliable for people who want current graphics and extra options. (Shooting chickens instead of bullets, infinite energy and custom enemy skins are my favourites.)Determined players will have arange of options with graphics and tweaks if they look hard enough. But the games look itself should be enough for the average player. It is something that it prides itself on, although it is less desirable nowadays.The Idea for the story is very well done! The Fact that is isnt a prequel nor sequel really shows the sophistication in the story. It happens exactly on the side of the main plot. Which is rare to see nowadays! It basically deepens the overall story that you play through.The Length is obviousy going to be shorter. But at 3-4 hours, it isnt what players really deserved here. No matter how deep the plot might be, the raw length has to be at least 6-10 hours. Although since this tells a side story, it can be let off.In terms of new addition to gameplay from the first game, not much has really changed. Although there is a new weapon which is amazing (Dual SMG's). Overall Combat and Gunplay hasnt changed, this is mainly because it was released very close after crysis 1 so the devs didnt feel like they needed to add anything. Also since it happens at the same time, itd have to make sense on that scale.Thats enoguh Briefing, heres the Pros and Cons:PROS:+ Better optimized to run with more Builds/systems than Crysis 1 since it is newer+ Beautiful graphics and scenery, much like the first game which provided a Lush wide area for most of the game.+ Good choice of main character with a mysterious past and a great personality. Tough Guy persona, with some english stereotypes and friendly rivalry with his squad mates.+ Large Levels with some side objectives at times. (Go to x to extract intel is a common one.)+ Intense firefights and action packed gameplay often possible with multiple approaches (eg: Stealth and Action), much like the far cry series!+ Nice straight forward story that features Crucial aspects of the Lingshen Island Incident.The Ending is great as well! It basically ties the two games together like a neat knot at the end.+Stealth and All guns blazing approaches add some Replayability, especially in the harder difficulties.+The Vehicles included (Same as the first game) make travering the map much faster! You wont want to rely on your suit for travel, unfortuntely.+Explosions and other visual effects are very well done (Always reminds me of Far cry).. Basically all PC's can run this game now, and thats awesome! The only things that stop people from getting it are the price and a basic interest in FPS games.+Once again, the pacing is reminiscent of an Action Movies such a Rambo and even some general parts from Independance day!It even has a Human Antagonist (A Korean Mastermind named General Lee kim Sun! The Chase to capture/kill him really represents the backbone of the story. But the Main"mission" is of course pursuing a Top-Secret Nuclear Warhead that intel believes the Koreans possess. Thats a really dumbed down verison of the summary. If you even remotely liked any of that. Please Get this!+Did i mention shooting Chickens as bullets?CONS:- As it is a standalone game that has to live in the first games shadow, it is going to be very short (3-5 hours max played at the highest difficulty=Delta) Although length of playthrough will obviously depend on the players approach (Completionist, speedrunner, Stealth-focused, etc.)- Unimpressive voice acting from some of the cast, some scenes could have had a stronger impact if the voice acting was more convincing!- Most levels have a much smaller map-area than Crysis 1, i guess size does matter..- Not much long term replayability since it is very linear and theres no unlockables or a big reward for finishing it either.- Full price tag definetely does not justify the short campaign at all!-Old game=Old issues that fit Old Pc's-The game is mainly there to fill in plot gaps, not to introduce lots of new mechanics, weapons, characters or better graphics. This is good for fans of the series obviosuly, but people that buy this game to get into the series will be worse off.Overall I really enoyed this game, but i had to pay attention to cutscenes or i would miss lots of important info! Flashbacks were a great addition as well, but having a Main Boss to pursue throughout the game was definetely my favourite Section. If you liked the first game and want to continue the ride, Definetely get this! However if you like the information that i provided about it and want to understand the whole story, start from the beginning. I makes a big difference. I would recommended this to any Lovers of FPS, Sci Fi or just general action games.I rate this game an 8.5/10!The first two games are so different from crysis 2 and 3 so this could be a suitable stopping point for some players if they wanted. Buy this on sale, it would be a Crysis if you didnt buy this!Leave a comment below as usual with any questions. Thanks for reading, now if you'll excuse me my Nano-suit needs charging-Kyle

												In the original Crysis, you fought off North Koreans, discovered an extra-terrestrial plot, and began the fight for humanity, all as the special-ops agent codenamed Nomad. But as you saved the day in the main storyline, your cohort Psycho was off on his own mission. Warhead shows you what he was up to, by putting you in his head and unleashing you against the dastardly enemies who stand in your nanosuit-powered way.Crysis is an open-ended first-person shooter in which how you proceed is really up to you. Set on a beautiful tropical island filled with lush scenery, flora and fauna, you're equipped with a special nanosuit that allows you to cloak, speed up, increase your strength, or increase your defence. This nanosuit affords you a number of options in how you want to take on your enemies: do you sneak up behind them, grab hold of your target, and toss them into their ally? Or do you stay in the underbrush from a mile away and pick off your targets with a rifle? Of course, you can always just run into battle, guns-a-blazing, if that's your thing. Or punch everything with super strength, sending it skidding across the ground. The possibilities are endless, and it leads to replay certain encounters again and again, just to see the different results.Warhead doesn't really deviate too much from this formula, but that's alright, because it doesn't need to. Some level design does change, though. Levels are fairly smaller in this expansion, but with more in them. In the original, while you spent most of your time walking through long, lush, but boring valleys, this one had the action more condensed. The pacing is much improved, leading to less running around and more shooting/punching/tossing/humiliating your foes. Overall the game can last about six to seven hours, depending on your play style, so while it not be a lengthy campaign, it's a good addendum to the original's plot.Additionally, as opposed to the sudden appearance of aliens doesn't suddenly eliminate the Korean presence on the island like it did in the first game. Both groups will show up as your aggressors throughout the game, sometimes at the same time. This leads to you being able to get them to combat each other, letting you either slink away in the firefight or simply eliminate the last remaining forces.Crytek have also stated that the graphics have been optimized, and therefore aren't as system-taxing as the original Crysis. While I've heard some reports to verify this, I've also heard that there are some problems with how the game goes about its graphical business. While I didn't directly notice these problems with the exception of an odd framerate hiccup, reports of unreasonable slowdown and graphical glitches are somewhat common.While Crysis: Warhead doesn't really bring anything new to the series gameplay-wise, the expanded-upon storyline and better pacing of the game will intrigue any that enjoyed the original Crysis. Wide open settings, fast-paced action, and the ability to fling someone across a great distance make it a fun game to play, especially with all the different ways to approach a situation. So, while it may not be everyone's cup of tea, if you enjoy a bit of choice with your explosions, and enjoyed the original, Warhead is definitely the game for you.

												Crysis Warhead represents the apex of the Crytek sandbox FPS genre. This is the one and only time the formula's been applied flawlessly. Far Cry 1 brims with promise but is plagued with staggeringly unfair AI and bad checkpointing that can make the game sometimes unfun. Crysis 1 starts off incredible but devolves into linear COD-esque nonsense two-thirds of the way through. After Warhead, Crysis got consolized and turned into a generic linear shooter, and Far Cry got open-worldized and turned into a generic Ubigame.But, for the brief duration of Crysis Warhead's 7-hour running time, the style is done perfectly. It's linear, of course, in the sense that you need to go from point A to point B, but there are innumerable paths to take and a variety of available playstyles. Want to stealth through most of the game? No problem! Want to kill everybody? No problem! There is a slightly more linear train level, but you can just jump off the train and sneak through the woods if you want (in fact, on the highest difficulty, you have to - staying on top of the train means insta-death).The story is inconsequential and won't make sense if you haven't played Crysis 1, and the game's still a system melter just like the original, but neither of those things diminish how much fun it is to play around in these environments. Thankfully, this game has quick save, so you can play around to your heart's content and try different things without worrying.Definitely worth the $20 asking price.

ber 8, 2015
												This game took every issue I had about the original Crysis, and improved upon them to the fullest extent possible. The result is a game that stands on its own as "better than the original". The characters (now you play as "Psycho", Nomad's former SAS teammate) are now vastly improved, with the game exploring the depths of Raptor Team's  former history. Whereas I did not find General Kyong to be a wholly believable character, I found the ruthless Colonel Lee to be a far more engaging (not to mention competent) villain- it's a pity one could not fight him at the end, like the General in Crysis. So yes, the characters are better. The storyline is slimmed down, which in my mind provided greater coherence throughout the game. Essentially, the player pursues Colonel Lee, who is in possession of some valuable alien technology, all over the island. The missions are now highly varied, from standoffs with hordes of aliens in the frozen mountains to a vehicular frag-fest atop a moving train. The missions absolutely kick-♥♥♥! The weapons have now been substantially modified, with tons of new ones being added in. I absolutely enjoyed the new turrets, the 20mm definitely being the superior one. The Gauss rifle is slightly weaker in this game, which was a little disappointing, but the Sniper Rifle is as accurate and deadly as in the last game. The Hurricane minigun is as good for throwing up a wall of lead as in the previous installation. The last thing I want to point out (aside from briefly mentioning the awesome soundtrack that accompanied this game) is the massive changes to vehicles. The APC has its moments, but without a doubt the best have to be the BMP-esque tank with the 30-or so-mm autocannon, and the AA installation, with its' guided missles and awe-inspiring flak cannons. I missed the vehicular combat in Crysis, and felt that that was an avenue which the developers could expand upon. Here, they have done so. Nothing is quite as thrilling as manning the AA battery and shooting down alien after alien during the final swarm (I have a thing for AA vehicles, as seen by my admiration for the Shilka in Arma: Cold War Assault).This game DESERVES a 10/10, but JUST because it is not Arma: Cold War Assault or Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl, I have to take off a small point. It's a clerical issue- anyone who reads this review will know what the real score is!9.9/10

												First off, I would like to give Crysis Warhead a neutral rating.The game is good for many reasons which other reviewers already discussed and I agree.There is graphical fidelity, exploration of the gameworld (though I did not bother with it) and mostly satisfying combat.Unfortunately when facing many enemies and the bullets started flying my rig would not keep up the performance to show fluid combat in those high ("enthusiastic") graphics. But instead another nameless pilot (/soldier) died and Psycho copes with this heavy loss by drowning some unknown, unlucky, wounded enemy. Which I came to realize later.. disappointing me subsequently again.If Crysis Warhead were an expansion or DLC of the original Crysis (which it is in a way) I would have given it a positive rating but since it is considered a standalone I see it falling just below the threshold to recommend you playing it.I would recommend buying Crysis Warhead on sale if you liked the original. 												Crysis is the original game.Crysis Warhead is this game.Crysis Wars is defunct multiplayer.Crysis 2 is the proper sequel but plays very differently than the above.Crysis 3 (and 4) are on "Origin" not Steam.Background:See my earlier review for Crysis the original.  This time you play as Psycho during the sections spent apart from Nomad (the player) in the original game.  This game looks the same but runs smoother on modern cards (GTX 970) and all but the hardest difficulty now use auto ammo pickup which is so much better.  Vehicles start in third person.  The UI isn't really improved from the first, though it tries.  There are definitely more weapons to play with but it doesn't change much.  This game is very clearly the polished version of Crysis original.  Way more fairly long cut scenes.Gameplay:Another first person shooter in a mostly open world.  This one is more linear but has less sections that you get stuck working through and hate.You start off with all suit powers (hold middle click and drag in a direction):- default is armor which includes faster health regen- then cloak is overpowered (drains power as you move and drops if you attack) yet fails at melee range.- strength makes you jump higher and absorb more falling damage- speed makes you run faster, really fast for a short timeGood to know:Fairly unforgiving again (seriously consider playing on easy and you will still die a bunch).Falling damage can kill (use strength to minimize).You can breath underwater.There's also a separate night vision that drains a separate power meter.Armored vehicles require explosives to destroy.You can only carry a few kinds of weapons at a time, but can swap on the fly and recall a previous weapon's ammo pool (which is the only reason to swap late game).Health is regenerative but the meter is on screen.  No achievements or collectibles, just secondary objectives with no impact aside from providing another ammo cache.  Relatively short compared to today's titles (7-10 hours).Verdict:Worth $5.  You could skip the original to play this one in a pinch, but it explains a lot more of the story (maybe watch YouTube videos of the original).  But play 1 first if you're planning to.  Read my review of 2 before you buy it, it's a very different game.

												I rate the game Crysis: Warhead 4/5. Good.This game is better than the original crysis in every respect except it seems to have no idea how to tell a coherent story. Indeed, if I had not played the original game first I would not have any clear idea as to what is going on in this game and as a result it is very necessary to play the original to understand what this game's plot is about. But....the graphics are better, the game runs better, there are even fewer bugs and the same great enemy AI has been retained.Like its predecessor, this game encourages you to "think outside of the box" and come up with more innovative solutions to tactical situations than some other games would have you do...but also like its predecessor if you think too far out of the box or get too innovative you can fully expect the game to come up with some crazy, contrived way of instantly killing you. Good example: I decided to bypass a large battle area and outflank all the opponents in an entire battlefield by swimming underwater. A giant shark came by and instantly killed my character, despite the fact that he's wearing a power armor that can deflect .50 caliber bullets with relative ease. Oh well.But despite its intrinsic and inescapably linear design, this game is still a lot of fun to play. It's loud, action packed and full of between level cutscenes that somehow bridge the gap (or straddle the fence between irritating and campy. This game also gets an honorable mention from me also because it has one of the best train battles (where you jump from one railroad car to another wild-west style) that I have ever seen (the very best was still in Soldier of Fortune however). The music was better in this iteration of crysis also but still not spectacular enough to warrant getting a soundtrack for it. This is a game that was fun enough that I'd consider playing it through on an even higher difficulty sometime or other...if there wasn't such a huge selection of other games out there vying for my attention. In short, this game has all the strengths of the original (except anything approaching a coherent story) and none of the weaknesses. Be warned though, it is unfortunately rather short. Intense but short.

												Just like Crysis.. i wish there was a vote inbetween thumbs up and down. This is another "meh" title. I had high hopes for Warhead. Crysis leaves you on a MASSIVE cliffhanger and I figured this game would go back and you would continue on. In Crysis the characters "Nomad" and "Prophet" go into the alien sphere for what seems like an epic battle. That game ends abruptly right there and leaves you hanging. Warhead instead of doing what it was supposed to do, just puts you in the shoes of a completely different soldier "Psycho" who you see for a short while at the start of Crysis. Worst still, it takes place along side Crysis on a seperate part of the island. Its not a prequel or a sequel. That's pretty annoying. The only justice in this title is that at least is wraps up Psycho's story somewhat.. problem is the ending of Crysis happens after the ending of Warhead, so even though Warhead wraps up, it can't close off the open story created by Crysis. Seriously, this is another example of a tech demo and not a full game. Worse still, Crysis at least showed off some amazing design and some really interesting visuals... even if there was no gameplay present during those moments. Warhead on the otherhand just recycles literally all of it's visual content from Crysis and doesn't add anything to the experience. Psycho's storyline is uninteresting. You spend the whole game trying to capture a "thing" in a box. Once you get it the game doesn't have the good grace of even telling you what it is... however by the time I was done I was so burned out on the experience I didn't care. I didn't expect the game to answer the questions it poses so I wasn't dissapointed this go around. I was expecting mediocrity and I got it. By why still a thumbs up? True I want to give this a nuetral rating, but it is still fun in it's own right. It barely leans towards a thumbs up, even less so than Crysis did and I was feeling conflicted by that one. I'm 7 years late to this party, but at least writing out this review feels cathartic.

												For this review, I will also be reviewing Crysis 1. Nothing makes you feel old like realizing this game is 10 years old. It still holds up as well in terms of gameplay and graphics. I loved the level of customization the player has in terms of mission accomplishment and fighting the enemy with a stardard assortment of weapons. Overall they were good but sometimes my character would die instantly just by touching a crate very slightly or even throwing an object, which can be very iritating. The vehicle combat is clunky, and often I find myself more interested in blowing up vehicles than driving them. The enemy A.I is smart for the most part, but often I will see them pushing themselves against a wall like Kim-Jun Ill ordered them into time-out.Warhead itself is a good stand-alone expansion, being able to play as the great British Psycho we all know and love from the series. The level designs were done well and some of the vehicle combat was improved. Though it may be great campaign, don't expect much in terms of a couple new weapons and vehicles. Overall, the graphics hold up even after 10 years, and the camplay is just as good as I remember it.I give Crysis 1 a 9/10, and Crysis Warhead a 8.5/10

												The Good: More Crysis, better balancing of open environments and closed, more big aliens to killThe Bad: Nothing really new, still requires a monster to run, story is still lackingThe original Crysis was a technical phenomenon with a lot of great elements that worked, and Warhead is the exact same game with a different setting. This is both good and bad, but more positives than anything. You play Psycho, one of the special forces soldiers who was sent in with the original game’s Nomad. This is his story and what happened to him while separated from Nomad. While the core story of Crysis wasn’t too interesting there is a better mix between the open world and corridors. The game still gives you the option to choose to approach each objective by sneaking, sniping, driving, or guns blazing.The game has more of a variety of objectives such as a train ride, and killing the larger aliens which can be pretty fun. There aren’t any new weapons, and everything is pretty much the same. If you’re looking for Crysis 2.5 with this you’re going to be disappointed. While the game plays exactly like the first there are more cinematic moments such as running from a giant alien, and towards the end the game gets really epic. There are more aliens involved this time around instead of just mostly KPA soldiers. I still would have liked to see different alien types, and maybe make the game a bit more scripted since the game is so short.The game still looks the same with no graphical improvements at all. You still need an ultra powerful machine to run this on highest settings with DirectX10. Even my monster computer struggles to keep the FPS at a non-choppy rate during large firefights. The game is also more forgiving this time around as I only died maybe a dozen times during the whole campaign. The mass of enemies are easier to take on since the game seems to feel more balanced and the close quarters environments seem to be designed for this too.While I wish there would have been new weapons, new enemies, and totally new locales it works with the game’s story. Warhead will really make Crysis fans happy and add an extra 4-5 hours and give you more of a back story to what happened to the strange Psycho.--Score: 8.5/10

												The Good: More Crysis, better balancing of open environments and closed, more big aliens to killThe Bad: Nothing really new, still requires a monster to run, story is still lackingThe original Crysis was a technical phenomenon with a lot of great elements that worked, and Warhead is the exact same game with a different setting. This is both good and bad, but more positives than anything. You play Psycho, one of the special forces soldiers who was sent in with the original game’s Nomad. This is his story and what happened to him while separated from Nomad. While the core story of Crysis wasn’t too interesting there is a better mix between the open world and corridors. The game still gives you the option to choose to approach each objective by sneaking, sniping, driving, or guns blazing.The game has more of a variety of objectives such as a train ride, and killing the larger aliens which can be pretty fun. There aren’t any new weapons, and everything is pretty much the same. If you’re looking for Crysis 2.5 with this you’re going to be disappointed. While the game plays exactly like the first there are more cinematic moments such as running from a giant alien, and towards the end the game gets really epic. There are more aliens involved this time around instead of just mostly KPA soldiers. I still would have liked to see different alien types, and maybe make the game a bit more scripted since the game is so short.The game still looks the same with no graphical improvements at all. You still need an ultra powerful machine to run this on highest settings with DirectX10. Even my monster computer struggles to keep the FPS at a non-choppy rate during large firefights. The game is also more forgiving this time around as I only died maybe a dozen times during the whole campaign. The mass of enemies are easier to take on since the game seems to feel more balanced and the close quarters environments seem to be designed for this too.While I wish there would have been new weapons, new enemies, and totally new locales it works with the game’s story. Warhead will really make Crysis fans happy and add an extra 4-5 hours and give you more of a back story to what happened to the strange Psycho.--Score: 8.5/10

During the story in Crysis I, Psycho get separated from Nomad, in order to fulfill another important mission. This new story is quite good and it's connected to the story in Crysis I, which is awesome. Even though it doesn't provide too much info about aliens and characters, I liked the way it was linked to the main story, so this is why I gave a better score. If I could have given a better score, I would, this expansion is improved on almost every aspect. Gameplay: 9.5 out of 10First of all, I like to mention that this game is a bit harder than Crysis I, but this isn't because of AI improvement, but mostly because of more difficult enemies throught the game. While in the first Crysis, you fought KPA soldiers over 50 % of the game (which were quite weak even on Delta difficulty), in this DLC you'll only fight KPA soldiers during the first 10 % of the game. Instead of KPA soldiers, in Crysis Warhead you'll fight a lot of KPA Special Ops (which are bassically nano suit soldiers just like yourself), which are pretty damn good. The producers also included some alien packs that are immune to damage until you destroy the one that generates their shield. All this makes the game a bit more challenging than the first Crysis, which is a good improvement from my point of view. They also added new vehicules and new weapons like grenade launcher, new pistols, new grenades, all this further improves the overall gameplay. Great job ! Audio: 10 out of 10The audio is similar to the previous Crysis, so that means is excellent. Didn't noticed any differences here. AI Behavior: 9.5 out of 10The AI is better, because you don't have to fight too many KPA soldiers, instead you have to fight a lot of aliens, KPA Special Ops and some bosses. The KPA Special Ops are quite good because they use nano grenades to deactivate your suit before moving to attack, the aliens instead, have the same behavior like in Crysis I, so for more details see that review.Multiplayer: not testedAs with Crysis I, I couldn't test the multiplayer since the servers were deactivated. There are some instructions on the internet on how you can play multiplayer, but I didn't bother to try.Overall: 9.7 out 10A lot of improvements done in this expansion compared to the previous Crysis, that makes this game even better. On top of all this, Crysis Warhead is a stand alone game and doesn't require the original Crysis to be played, but in my opionion is very recommended that you play the first Crysis before checking Crysis Warhead, so that you may have a better understanding of what is happening during the storyline. 100 % recommend, a true clasic masterpiece to the fps genre.

However game still runs like nightmare on 64-bit systems, and that's a shame, so you’ll have constant crashes, random FPS drops and so on. Psycho story-line is a parallel of Nomads from the original game, and he goes on to hunt North-Korean officer Lee, who's in charge of evacuating a mystical container which might have a nuclear warhead in it. Gameplay is pretty much the same what you expect from Crysis, however, game escalates pretty quickly, you  acquire most powerful weapons early in the game and combining it with Nano-suit's abilities you feel like unstoppable Juggernaut of death, and to be honest, that's just so much fun to play. Maybe if the game was bit longer it would outstay it’s welcome, but for campaign that is about 8 hours long, it was perfect. Standalone expansion also introduces some new weapons like dual wielding fully automatic pistols and granade launcher, new vehicles as well as some new enemy types. In the end, I really enjoyed Crysis Warhead, it’s a definite improvement in every way, but the technical problems and Crytech’s attitude to fix them for new’er systems just pisses me of. De todas formas pude jugar sin problemas y no como me ocurrio con "Crysis" y sus bajadas brutales de framerate.Tengo que reconocer que lo pase mucho mejor jugando a Warhead que al primer Crysis.
